description: Oksana Lintz privately decides to withhold BCI abuse records and instead releases technical protocols for local self-governance, hoping to encourage reforms without inciting mass outrage.
Neighborhoods across Stenograd receive clear guides for forming their own access rules and councils. Local governance systems emerge rapidly, each adapting protocols to fit community needs.
Council delegates attempt to coordinate and negotiate standards but are met with mixed reactions as some districts embrace self-governance and others reject outside interference.

Old BCI records begin to resurface in local debates, with districts referencing past compliance histories to shape inclusion policies, reviving tensions despite official attempts to suppress abuse files.
A citywide conference of neighborhood representatives ends without a unified platform. Uncertainty grows about Stenograd's ability to maintain citywide coherence as local differences deepen.
